People were buying at 30 in case it does not give them a chance lower such as at 29.35. So I think likely it can gap higher and bounce Monday even if the markets are not bouncing. To hedge I guess one could buy futures contracts Sunday night?

Message.Title: "Goodhair" signs the ridiculous "Merry Christmas bill" into law
Message.Msg: Real Time's Bill Maher took Texas Gov. "Goodhair" Rick Perry to task for signing the ridiculous "Merry Christmas bill" into law, which is supposed to protect Christmas and "other holiday celebrations in Texas public schools from legal challenges." MAHER: New Rule: If you're thinking about the sanctity of Christmas in June, just stop. This week Texas Gov. Rick Perry signed the "Merry Christmas bill," protecting people who say "Merry Christmas" from the people who wish they'd say something else, who total somewhere between three and nobody. Come on. It's the first day of summer. Can’t we wait to do this until Christmas season really starts -- on the last day of summer? They're not going to stop with this stuff as long as they think it's scoring them points with their wingnut base

Message.Title: What is the 'Cloud'?
Message.Msg: The 'Cloud' is ethereal and scalable. It's somewhat abstract but it's free and and not prone to regulatory restricitions. Because anyone can use it, it is democratic. Outside of external controls it's a favorite of businesses and individuals and that is why corporations are employing it, though no one understands it (See Ellison, Larry). Business are going to the 'Cloud' because if you don't go there you will be 'Cloudless'-a conditon no one wants to be in-except maybe pilots. But put your stuff in the 'Clloud' at your own risk. Several people that I've read about have lost their stuff in the "Cloud'. Also once in the "Cloud' someone else might claim your stuff which, if you've worked on it for 10 years would be a bummer. This little essay may or may not go into the 'Cloud'-no one knows but if they do they are not telling.

Topic.Title: "Goodhair" signs the ridiculous "Merry Christmas bill" into law

Message.Msg: at least the ban on large sugar drinks would do a good service..... fighting obesity.... USA did just fine before they began pushing supersize everything.... junk food pushers are like heroin and meth dealers in many ways......... [large sugar drink ban ] would address one of the fundamental causes of obesity—the growing portion size of sweetened drinks,” Dr. Y. Claire Wang, one of the researchers, said in a statement. The ban was originally proposed by Bloomberg last year. It was blocked by a judge in March and is back in appeals court this week. The U.S. leads the world in soda consumption as more and more American adults and children become obese.

Message.Title: Long Bet - I bought 150k of ORCL at 30.21. You will be kicking yourself if you sell here. Safe bet below
Message.Msg: Here is my long strategy --- I know Oracle can dip lower, but with a market cap this big, I'm in for 3 months with a trailing stop at 33.00. There is too much pressure on ORCL -- if sales continue to disappoint they will cut their prices and provide incentive to long term contracts. They will find a way to increase earnings. Look at their history of missing earnings 3 times in a row (NOT LIKELY) (and this last miss was an overreaction) An insider sold 85k at around 34.00 prior to earnings release. After these alliances with Salesforce and MSFT -- Im waiting for a tech rally that will get me 20-23% gain. We'll revisit this in three months, and I think I might be pleasantly surprised. I did this with Dell and had the same results. P/E is too low for it to fall lower than 29.58 unless something serious like Housing Sales (which can affect whole market) is poor on Tuesday or Bernanke steps in again and stops bond buying. Wont happen either. Get in while you can, at a minimum ORCL will continue raising its dividend. A great long term bet. Dont be scared by the drop, very similar to March. As Guns N roses says -- Patience

Message.Title: Private insurers pay out tens of billions each year in fraudlulent claims
Message.Msg: and what do they care? They always hike your premium to cover all costs including fraud... "Coalition Against Insurance Fraud estimates that in 2006 a total of about $80 billion was lost in the United States due to insurance fraud.[4] According to estimates by the Insurance Information Institute, insurance fraud accounts for about 10 percent of the property/casualty insurance industry’s incurred losses and loss adjustment expenses.[5] The National Health Care Anti-Fraud Association estimates that 3% of the health care industry’s expenditures in the United States are due to fraudulent activities, amounting to a cost of about $51 billion.[6] Other estimates attribute as much as 10% of the total healthcare spending in the United States to fraud—about $115 billion annually................." (please stop being such white collar criminals you fraudsters!)
